Question: What is the practice of non-disputation?
Answer: All arhats are well-versed in the internal, but not so in the external.
If one is also well-versed in external times, it is called the practice of non-disputation.
What is internal time?
It refers to the afflictions within one's own mental continuum.
What is external time?
It refers to the afflictions within the mental continuum of others.
Preventing these afflictions is called being well-versed.
All arhats have already completely eliminated the afflictions within their own mental continuums.
As for the afflictions within the mental continuums of others, it is not certain.
If one can also prevent them, it is called the practice of non-disputation.
Some say:
Time refers to the three times,
namely the first part of the day, the middle part of the day, and the last part of the day.
Controlling the afflictions during these three times

All arhats have already completely eliminated the afflictions of the three times within their own mental continuums.
As for the afflictions of the three times within the mental continuums of others, it is not certain.
If one can also control them, it is called the practice of non-disputation.
Some say:
Time refers to the six times,
namely the first, middle, and last parts of the day and night.
At these six times, they control the afflictions and are called well-versed.
All arhats have already eliminated the afflictions in their own mental continuum at these six times.
As for the afflictions in the mental continua of others, they are not certain.
